text: @pxwilliamson @esascience It's relative but, in general, red is around 10K. Blue is perhaps 100K.
@pxwilliamson @esascience Paul, we use red for the longest wavelengths, blue the shortest. So, colour represents temperature: red coldest.
As @ESAHerschel "only" observed about 10% of the sky, detecting 2 million sources is pretty impressive.
Most of the 2 million sources detected by @ESAHerschel during its 4 year mission are distant galaxies.
44.8% of Herschel observations now appear in at least one publication. This number is increasing rapidly as scientists mine their data.
If you are into big numbers from @ESAHerschel, the Herschel Point Source catalogue is likely to list about 2 million detected sources.
Thanks very much to everyone. @ESA_Herschel has now passed 30 000 followers. Lots more science to come from the mission though.
@David_Scanlan It shows us how lucky we were with @ESA_Herschel. MOC said that they had never seen a count without a hitch before.
If anyone has any doubts how complicated a launch is, the @NASA_Orion is showing it. So many systems that have to work perfectly first time.
New, young stars, heat the dust, so the blue colour traces where stars are forming in Orion's Sword: http://t.co/FPeXPHA6ZU
The image is 1.3x2.4 degrees & corresponds to Orion's Sword, a region of intense star formation: red is the coldest dust, blue the warmest.

The glowing jewels od @ESAHerschel: http://t.co/3uVpVoD5lN. A 12 degree sweep along the Galactic Plane.
And today, @ESAHerschel is a whopping 65.9 million km from Earth. It is not moving away quickly (1.4m/s), but it all adds up.
Five years ago today, final preparations for the @ESAHerschel & @ESAPlanck launch were under way. Time flies!
One year ago Herschel was just starting its programme of technology tests after the helium ended.
@BrunoMerin Now it's an even bigger adventure: save all Herschel's knowledge for posterity.
Just over 2 weeks more and we would have been able to celebrate 4 years of helium in space. Not bad when we expected only 3.5 years.
It is hard to believe that exactly one year ago yesterday the last drop of @ESAHerschel's helium evaporated.
RT @NASA: Scientist using @ESAHerschel data have discovered a young galaxy acting in mature ways! http://t.co/vwVWT01oXP   http://t.co/QgAk…

retweeted_status.text: Scientist using @ESAHerschel data have discovered a young galaxy acting in mature ways! http://t.co/vwVWT01oXP   http://t.co/QgAk5X5qLr

text: RT @NASAJPL: 13 going on 30? Young galaxy seen by @ESAHerschel is surprisingly well behaved. http://t.co/qMZkqPI4Fr http://t.co/aRamxhBxKS

retweeted_status.text: 13 going on 30? Young galaxy seen by @ESAHerschel is surprisingly well behaved. http://t.co/qMZkqPI4Fr http://t.co/aRamxhBxKS

text: If you want to learn about reducing & analysing @ESAHerschel spectroscopy, have a look at the material available at http://t.co/bISgzHTulx …
Around 50 people attended last week's on-line spectroscopy workshop. Videos  of all the talks will be posted at http://t.co/bISgzHTulx
The on-line @ESAHerschel spectroscopy workshop last week was a big success with astronomers from round the world connecting for the talks.
Herschel is drifting away at a relaxed 1.6m/s and has now moved into the constellation of Cancer but, at mag. 27.1, tricky to find!
@ESAHerschel is now 65 million km from Earth (that's 169 Lunar Distances), trailing us by 50º in the Earth´s orbit..
@ESAHerschel continues to drift away from Earth at 1.7m/s. It is now 0.43AU (64.4 million km) away in the Milky Way in Gemini.
Cosmologists! We have just created @ESAHerschel #COSMOS #PACS images with all the observations combined. Get them at http://t.co/BQdj99sUU3
You can follow our @ESAHerschel on-line #spectroscopy #workshop from the 23 to 25 April from your home/institute! http://t.co/R6htnC0Z84
Today & tomorrow HSC hosts an on-line spectroscopy workshop to teach users of @ESAHerschel data how to process it most effectively.
The 5th anniversary of the launch of @ESAHerschel & @Planck is just 3 weeks away. Still so much to do before we shut up shop in 2017!
As of tonight @ESAHerschel is now 62.3 million km from Earth & receding at a stately 2.0m/s.& magnitude 27.0 in southern Gemini.
@ESAHerschel will be holding a 5th Anniversary of launch celebration in Paris in May during the big Ground Segment meeting.
Five years ago today @ESAHerschel & @Planck were in the last stages of preparation for launch. How time flies! It feels just like yesterday.
@Planck @astronomyblog @planet4589 @dalcantonJD All pieces of the Herschel Planck constellation are under control and safe.
@Planck @astronomyblog @planet4589 @dalcantonJD You can find the Herschel-Planck Sylda orbit solution here: http://t.co/ZDDWCFcnzI Back 2025
@Planck @astronomyblog @planet4589 @dalcantonJD Tracked May 15- Aug 15, 2009. Made 2 orbits of Earth before escaping into heliocentric orbit
If you are interested in galaxies the Herschel Reference Survey has a really nice site: http://t.co/vsgkDayWVF. 323 galaxies.
Try out a few popular targets such as M31, the Orion Nebula, M101 or M104 and see what @ESAHerschel found here: http://t.co/gTBvR3gGSM.
Thousands of other @ESAHerschel postcard images are available at http://t.co/gTBvR3gGSM by typing in the name of the object to find.
Go to http://t.co/gTBvR3gGSM and type in "Churyumov-Gerasimenko"to see the postcard images of the (then) faint and distant comet.
Congratulations to our colleagues at @ESA_Rosetta on their first images of Comet Churyumov-Gerasimenko. @ESAHerschel looked at it in 2010.

Smart work from Bruno Merin & Mar Sierra at the Herschel Science Centre to program this:

http://t.co/dz537FqQV7

You can look at the galaxies in visible light, as seen by Herschel, or a mix of the two. Zoom in to see them bigger:

http://t.co/dz537FqQV7
Compare the galaxies from the Herschel Reference Survey in optical and far-infrared. The result is really beautiful:  http://t.co/dz537FqQV7
Flags fly at half mast this week at the European Space Astronomy Centre for the death of Adolfo Suarez. http://t.co/ggMj1hMkpn

@ESAHerschel's galaxies in visible and infrared light:

http://t.co/QvNFeq1iel

Big image!! 

http://t.co/CS8TxvSp0C

The Herschel Reference Survey: http://t.co/vkORnzgoyG 

Images of hundreds of nearby galaxies observed by @ESAHerschel .
One of the less known benefits of the @ESAHerschel mission is to understand the conditions at L2 for future missions.
The Sun comes back to life.again with an X5 flare. Herschel & @ESAPlanck spent more than 4 years together helping to monitor space weather.
It's hard to believe that, in just a few weeks, it will be the fifth anniversary of @ESAHerschel's launch. Time flies when you are busy!
Congratulations to our colleagues at @ESAGaia on their first image. We know how hard these first few weeks are from our own experience!!
